abstract.text: An abstract class that defines the interface for subclassers to interact with the screen saver infrastructure.

inlineContent.text: provides the interface for your screen saver, including the content you animate onscreen and an optional configuration sheet. Create your own custom subclass and add it to your screen saver bundle. Use your subclass to create the animations that you want to appear onscreen, and to specify additional animation details.
When someone previews your screen saver in System Preferences, the system instantiates your
You can draw from your view’s
method, or you can draw directly from the
method. If you prefer to use the
method and specify the portions of your view that require updates.

abstract.text: Marks the region of the view within the specified rectangle as needing display, increasing the view’s existing invalid region to include it.
Animate screen savers, and interact with the screen saver infrastructure.
A class that defines a set of methods for saving and restoring user defaults for screen savers.
An abstract class that defines the interface for subclassers to interact with the screen saver infrastructure.
Advances the screen saver’s animation by a single frame.
The time interval between animation frames.
Returns the type of backing store you want for your screen saver’s window.
The window that contains the controls to configure the screen saver.
Draws the screen saver view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the screen saver has an associated configuration sheet.
Creates a newly allocated screen saver view with the specified frame rectangle and preview information.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the screen saver is animating.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the screen saver view is set to a size suitable for previewing its content.
Indicates whether to perform a gradual screen fade when the system starts and stops your screen saver’s animation.
Activates the periodic timer that animates the screen saver.
Deactivates the timer that advances the animation.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
